Award.AwardTitle: Mortgage Design in an Equilibrium Model of the Housing Market

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the wake of the Great Recession, there has been substantial discussion about how the design of various mortgage products contributed to falling house prices, rising default, and contractions in consumption, output, and employment. In particular, many observers have suggested simple modifications to standard fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages might have helped to cushion the blow of a sharp housing downturn. Analyzing the costs and benefits of various mortgage designs is complicated, because in response to changes in mortgage contracts, households will change their prepayment, refinancing, default, and consumption behavior, lenders will change their lending standards and interest rates, and all of these actions will feed back into house prices, further affecting lender and household actions. There is no existing research that analyzes mortgage design in light of these complicated feedbacks. This project will fill the gap with a theoretical economic model that is fit to data, which will allow the researchers to simulate the housing market and boarder economy under different mortgage contracts and monetary policies. Because mortgages are the largest debt obligations of the vast majority of households, improving the mortgage system to stabilize the housing market and consumption has the potential to have large benefits for society. This project will also help inform the ongoing policy debate on how to reform the housing finance system.

Because household behavior, lender behavior, and house prices all depend on one another, an analysis of mortgage design requires a general equilibrium analysis of housing and mortgage markets that incorporates substantial heterogeneity across households and aggregate shocks. The investigators will use tools from heterogeneous agent macroeconomics to create a quantitative general equilibrium life cycle model with aggregate shocks in which households have realistic long-term mortgages and a rich set of choices as to whether to prepay, refinance, move, or default, lenders set interest rates for different mortgage contracts in response to prepayment and default risk, and household and lender decisions aggregate up to determine house prices. The model will be calibrated to the U.S. housing market, with a focus on matching recent empirical evidence on how mortgage payment size and loan-to-value ratios affect default and consumption. The model will then be used to simulate how different mortgage contracts affect housing market volatility and particularly in busts like the Great Recession, allowing the researchers to understand the tradeoffs involved in mortgage design qualitatively and quantitatively. This project will also shed light on how these different mortgage contracts affect the transmission of monetary policy and how monetary policy affects the performance of various mortgage contracts by varying the extent to which the central bank adjusts interest rates in response to developments in the housing market and the real economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because the Great Recession and the wave of foreclosures that accompanied it was triggered by a housing boom and bust, a central concern of economists and policy makers in the last decade has been how to make housing markets be more resilient in the future. While some of this work has focused how to modify mortgages in a crisis, there is evidence of frictions that limit the efficacy of such modifications. Consequently, much of the discussion has shifted to how to design mortgages to automatically stabilize the housing market and provide relief to homeowners in the next housing bust.

The primary research paper supported by the grant studies how to best design mortgages to reduce housing market volatility and default in a housing bust. Our main finding is that mortgages that concentrate payment relief in a housing bust and recession do better than mortgages that spread payment reductions over the life of the mortgage. An example of this is a standard adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM), which lowers payments automatically when interest rates fall in the bust and then raise payments as interest rates rise when the economy improves. We find that relative to a standard fixed-rate mortgage (FRM), under an ARM, house prices fall by less, household spending is higher, and 23% fewer households default. Because ARMs have some downsides, we also analyze other mortgage designs that attempt to combine the best elements of the FRMs and ARMs. Our research will inform policy makers as they work to re-design the housing finance system and decide what the mortgages of the future should look like.

The grant also supported four strands of related work on the intersection of housing markets and the macroeconomy that fall under the umbrella of the original grant proposal. The first studies the effect of house prices on consumer spending. Prior work has shown that changes in house prices cause corresponding changes in consumption and that consequently the decline in house prices is important in explaining the decline in consumption in the Great Recession. Our work asks whether the relationship between house prices and consumption was stronger than before in the 2000s boom and bust. We find that it was not; if anything, it was slightly weaker in the 2000s boom and bust than it was in the 1980s and 1990s. This implies that house prices only had a strong effect on consumption in the Great Recession because the movement in house prices was so large. The historical stability of the relationship between house prices and consumption is important for policy makers who need to know the strength of this relationship to make good policy.

The second related paper studies the role of an expansion and contraction in mortgage credit in explaining the 2000s housing boom and bust. Some prior studies have found a significant role for credit in the boom and bust, while others have found almost no role for credit. We show that these contrasting findings are due to different assumptions economists have made about how easily homes can be converted between renter-occupied and owner-occupied. Based on new empirical evidence on the degree of convertibility, we conclude that credit does appear to play an important role, although not quite as important as some studies have suggested. This finding implies that policies that limit the expansion and contraction of mortgage credit can help stabilize housing markets.

The third related project studies the long-term effects of foreclosure on households using new statistical methods and a comprehensive data set on foreclosure in Cook County, Illinois. We find that foreclosures have very large long-term costs for foreclosed-upon homeowners, who experience housing instability, reduced homeownership, financial distress, moves to worse neighborhoods, and elevated divorce. We find only financial consequences for landlords and no adverse effects for renters whose landlord is foreclosed-upon. Our results imply that foreclosure is far more costly to society than previously thought. Our findings imply that the benefits of foreclosure mitigation policies are larger those used in previous policy cost-benefit analyses.

Finally, the grant has supported an ongoing project that studies the housing boom, bust, and rebound from 1998 to 2018 as a whole. While this project is still in progress, we preliminarily find that the boom, bust, and rebound are highly correlated and that cities that experienced a larger boom, bust, and rebound had larger growth in long-run fundamentals. The important role for fundamentals that we find stands in contrast to prior studies, which found that the boom and bust could not be explained by fundamentals.

Together, these projects shed light on the housing boom and bust, the role of mortgages and mortgage design in the boom and bust, and scope and ability of policy to reduce housing market fluctuations and default going forward.
